column7: The report also applies the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) standards, the most widely used global sustainability reporting standard. It requires us to apply a materiality lens to identify and report against the sustainability issues most essential to spark business and stakeholders.

column13: Spark has now deployed 5G into 77 locations, and following the allocation of 80MHz of C Band spectrum from the New Zealand Government, Spark continues working towards nationwide coverage. Spark is exploring 5G technology operating in the mmWave spectrum, and in July 2022, Spark conducted New Zealand's first rural trial of mmWave technology.

Spark IoT (Internet of Things) solutions have continued to grow, surpassing one million 'things' being connected via Spark's networks this financial year. IoT solutions enable businesses to monitor things in the natural and physical worlds around them, collecting data that can then be analyzed and used to inform decision-making.

Spark's purpose-built Innovation Studio in Auckland allows New Zealand businesses to explore and learn about emerging technologies across IoT, 5G, multi-access edge computing, and mixed reality. The studio also provides a space for our IoT team to work with selected businesses to co-create solutions that can help them solve the challenges they face.

Over the years, Spark has continued to develop its 'high-tech' capabilities, such as AI, machine learning, 5G standalone, multi-access edge computing and the Internet of Things. Over the next three years, Spark will bring its high-tech solutions together to deliver their customers converged, end-to-end business solutions.

Spark has been working with researchers from the University of Auckland to explore the potential of 5G to transform the world of industrial robotics. Industrial robots are commonly used in electronics, food and medical manufacturing as they can be programmed to carry out automated tasks with precision and accuracy.
